context: Post-fix re-audit after Plan 18-04 UX improvements. Testing the same user journeys with improvements applied.

findings.what_happened: ORIGINAL: The search box was grayed out with a small loading message that was easy to miss. NOW: When I land on the page, there is a prominent animated spinner with 'Loading Tribe data...' text below it. The spinner is centered and visible. I immediately understand the page is loading. The search box is still grayed out (which is correct -- it should not accept input until data is ready), but the spinner makes the wait obvious and expected.
findings.how_i_got_here: Opened the page for the first time.
findings.how_it_felt: Clear and professional. The spinner tells me something is happening. I am happy to wait a moment.
findings.suggestion: No further improvement needed. The loading state is now clear.
findings.fix_applied: 18-04 (786938a): Added CSS spinner animation with loading-spinner class, spinner div, loading-text styling.

findings.what_happened: Fuzzy search still works beautifully. 'Navaho' finds Navajo Nation. 'Standing Rock' finds Standing Rock Sioux Tribe. Partial searches produce correct results. The 'Also known as' hints remain excellent.
findings.how_it_felt: Pleasantly surprised, again. Still works well.

findings.what_happened: ORIGINAL: Two download buttons with no explanation of what each document contains. NOW: Each button has a description underneath. 'Internal Strategy' shows 'Detailed analysis with talking points for your team.' 'Congressional Overview' shows 'Facts-only briefing for congressional offices.' I now know exactly which document I need without guessing.
findings.how_i_got_here: Selected a Tribe and looked at the download buttons.
findings.how_it_felt: Clear and helpful. I know immediately that the Internal Strategy is for my team and the Congressional Overview is for Hill meetings. No guessing required.
findings.suggestion: No further improvement needed. The descriptions are concise and informative.
findings.fix_applied: 18-04 (786938a): Added doc-description span elements under each download button with audience-specific text.

findings.what_happened: ORIGINAL: The previous Tribe's card stayed visible while searching for a new one. NOW: When I start typing in the search box, the previous Tribe's card fades out smoothly. By the time I see the new search results, the old card is gone. When I select the new Tribe, a fresh card fades in. The transition is clean and there is no moment of confusion about which Tribe I am looking at.
findings.how_i_got_here: Selected a Tribe, then started typing to search for a different one.
findings.how_it_felt: Smooth and intuitive. The fade-out on new search input is a nice touch. The opacity transition (0.2s) is quick enough to feel responsive but slow enough to avoid jarring changes.
findings.suggestion: No further improvement needed. The transition is well-timed.
findings.fix_applied: 18-04 (786938a): Added hideCard() function triggered by search input event, CSS transition on opacity, data-visible attribute guard.

findings.what_happened: Everything still feels fast. Search results appear instantly. Card appears immediately. Downloads start without delay. No jank. The new spinner during initial load adds a professional feel. The card fade transition is smooth.

ORIGINAL: Error message said 'Failed to load Tribe data. Please try again later.' with no action. NOW: Error messages include a 'Refresh Page' link. The timeout message says 'Loading timed out. Refresh Page.' The general error says 'Failed to load Tribe data. Please try again in a few minutes or Refresh Page.' The 'Refresh Page' text is clickable and actually refreshes the page.
findings.how_it_felt: Empowered. I know what to do: click the link. The error message tells me the situation and gives me a clear next step.
findings.suggestion: No further improvement needed. The Refresh Page link is the right approach.
findings.fix_applied: 18-04 (786938a): Added buildErrorWithRefresh() function that creates safe DOM-based error messages with clickable Refresh Page link.

findings.what_happened: ORIGINAL: No privacy or data sovereignty statement anywhere on the page. NOW: The footer includes the text 'No tracking. No cookies. Your searches stay on your device.' in a subtle italic style. It is visible without being intrusive. When I see this, I feel reassured that my search activity is private. This is exactly the kind of trust signal that Tribal staff look for.
findings.how_i_got_here: Scrolled to the bottom of the page.
findings.how_it_felt: Reassured. The statement is honest and specific. It does not use generic privacy language -- it tells me exactly what is not happening (no tracking, no cookies). The 'Your searches stay on your device' part is particularly trust-building because it explains the technical architecture in human terms.
findings.suggestion: No further improvement needed. This is the right level of detail for a footer statement.
findings.fix_applied: 18-04 (d3d18af): Added footer-privacy paragraph with privacy statement.

findings.what_happened: Mobile experience remains excellent. Everything works at 375px. Touch targets are large enough. New document descriptions are readable on mobile. The spinner is centered. The privacy footer wraps correctly. Download button disabled state ('Downloading...') is visible.
findings.how_i_got_here: Viewed the page on a narrow viewport.
findings.how_it_felt: Good. No regressions from the new features.

findings.what_happened: ORIGINAL: Selecting a Tribe did not change the URL. NOW: When I select a Tribe, the URL updates to include #tribe=Navajo+Nation (or whatever the Tribe name is). If I copy this URL and paste it in a new tab, the page loads and automatically selects that Tribe, showing the card with download buttons. I can now share a direct link to a specific Tribe's information with a colleague.
findings.how_i_got_here: Selected a Tribe, looked at the URL bar, copied the URL, opened it in a new tab.
findings.how_it_felt: Delightful. This is exactly what I wanted. I can now email a colleague: 'Here is the page for your Tribe' with a direct link. The URL is human-readable too -- I can see the Tribe name right in the hash.
findings.suggestion: No further improvement needed. The hash-based URL approach is clean and works perfectly.
findings.fix_applied: 18-04 (786938a): Added updateHash() and handleHashNavigation() functions. URL updates via history.replaceState with #tribe=encodedName. On load, hash is parsed and Tribe auto-selected.

findings.what_happened: State filter still works correctly. Selecting a state shows all Tribes with correct counts. New screen reader announcement works (accessible, though I cannot hear it). Clicking a Tribe from the state list opens the card with descriptions.

Visual design remains professional and trustworthy. The new loading spinner adds a modern touch. The document descriptions add content depth to the card. The privacy footer adds credibility. The disabled 'Downloading...' state on the Download Both button provides clear feedback.
findings.how_it_felt: More confident than before. The small additions (spinner, descriptions, privacy note) collectively raise the polish level.
findings.suggestion: The design is strong and improved.

findings.what_happened: Would a Tribal Leader feel comfortable showing this to their council? Even more so now. The document descriptions help a leader choose the right document for their audience. The privacy footer provides a trust signal. The shareable URLs allow pre-meeting preparation. The loading spinner sets professional expectations. Yes, this is council-ready.
findings.how_i_got_here: Evaluated from a Tribal Leader's perspective.
findings.how_it_felt: Confident. The improvements address exactly the kinds of questions a council member might ask: 'What is each document?' and 'Is this site tracking us?'

overall_impression: This tool has improved notably since the first audit. Every concern I raised has been addressed thoughtfully. The loading state is now clear. The document types are now explained. The card transitions are smooth. Error messages are actionable. URLs are shareable. Privacy is stated explicitly. The fuzzy search remains excellent. The mobile experience is intact. The visual design is stronger with the small additions. I would not just recommend this to a colleague -- I would share a direct link to their Tribe's page.

trust_score_breakdown.search_quality: 10/10 -- Fuzzy matching, aliases, partial search all excellent
trust_score_breakdown.document_clarity: 9/10 -- Descriptions now explain each document type clearly (was 7/10)
trust_score_breakdown.error_handling: 9/10 -- Actionable messages with Refresh Page links (was 6/10)
